body:
We don't currently support any kind of metadata for folders, not even mod time.

Some backends could support this, but others such as OCI don't have directories (I think it works like s3 being a strictly key-value store but I may be wrong).

pardon a stupid q... I kinda assumed there is no diff between files and directories on key/value store. All are objects, which can be assigned metadata. rclone doesn't treat directories as such objects at all?

On object based systems, rclone does not store directory objects. There is no need as the pattern of objects shows the directory.

Hence no object to store metadata.

>On object based systems, rclone does not store directory objects. There is no need as the pattern of objects shows the directory.
Very much like a Git repo, right? Is this very fundamental decision in rclone or can be addressed perhaps as an option in backends?

Yes this is very much like a git repo.

It would be possible to change this but it would be quite a lot of work re-plumbing things througout rclone. For the object based backends we'd store an object with a name ending in `/` (rclone already knows how to ignore these).

Is this important to your companyu @novitk ? Maybe they'd like to sponsor the development of the feature?

This is for my own usage. Unfortunately I'm not a rich man, have zero Golang experience and not much free time. If there is some sort of crowdfunding/bounty setup I'd be willing to chip in up to say $200.

I'm willing to pledge $100 for full metadata preservation*. Unfortunately I don't have the clout to get my employer to sponsor it (I don't think they use rclone). @ncw do you use something like Bountysource?

\* by full metadata what I mean is that
```bash
user@A ~$ rclone copy important_docs S2:remote_archive
user@B ~$ rclone copy S2:remote_archive important_docs
```
should have the exact same result as
```bash
user@A ~$ rsync -aHAX important_docs B:/home/user/important_docs
```
where A and B are both linux systems.

I would also accept non-preservation of hardlinks (i.e., rsync without the `-H` option). But directory mtime and permissions are a must!
I think for file level metadata, we can use --metadata option with rclone

> I think for file level metadata, we can use --metadata option with rclone

Yes, but not for folders, so in the example above rclone and rsync would give different outputs.

> If there is some sort of crowdfunding/bounty setup I'd be willing to chip in up to say $200.

I'm willing to chip in as well. What's the total you're looking to raise?

issue.title: Feature request: Copy custom metadata on objects

milestone.title: Help Wanted
milestone.description:
Enhancements which might be useful, but currently aren't planned.

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
For object storage systems that support custom (user defined) metadata types, include a flag (`-meta`?) that will also copy custom metadata from source to destination. For example, if copying/migrating data from Amazon S3 to Swift, or from Swift to Swift, it would be very handy to be able to maintain any custom metadata set on the objects.

issue.title: Sync directory mtimes (folder modtime)

milestone.title: Soon
milestone.description: Issues which are a good idea but haven't been assigned a specific release yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
Per https://forum.rclone.org/t/change-directory-mtime-on-gdrive/3797

I‚Äôm syncing a bunch of backup directories to an encrypted GDrive.

The contents of those directories frequently change, and on my desktop this also changes the directories‚Äô last modified time. So I can go in nautilus or finder and sort by date modified and see the directories with the newest files on top.

Rclone doesn‚Äôt sync directory mtimes, so they all have the mtime of when they were first synced to GDrive.

***ncw note*** when this gets done we will need to update `rclone touch` too.

issue.title: Keep track of permissions...

milestone.title: Help Wanted
milestone.description:
Enhancements which might be useful, but currently aren't planned.

Any help doing these much appreciated.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
So, what about a way to save permissions for us linux users? Currently, if we backup our system information to the cloud (like acd) all permissions are lost due to the clouds not understanding permissions. If there is a cloud that keep them I don't know what it is! 

Anyway, since rclone can of course read the privileges, any way to store them in a hidden file? (or any file, you get the idea) then if you copy back from the remote, rclone can then rewrite the files/dir back to disk with the correct privileges? In theory seems possible, but my attempt to read your GO code Nick has shown me my GO fu is really lacking. 

I know that's a HUGE request, but maybe someone out there with strong GO FU would be interested?

body:
I had a quick thought about this. Would it be of interest if I could write a small command that copies dir modtimes from one remote to another (for backends that support it)? It would be intended as more of a short-term stop-gap to tide us over while we wait hopefully for full dir metadata support, which would be a much more complicated project.

Many backends (including `local` and `drive`) already support listing directory modtime, like:

```
rclone lsf --dirs-only -R --format "pt" src_remote:path
```

So the command I'm imagining would do basically the equivalent of the above command, then loop through all the results and do something like  `err = dir.SetModTime(ctx, t)`  for each corresponding dir on the dest. (Probably with a `--modify-window` check first, and maybe also support for `--update`.)

An alternate approach might be to tack it on to the end of `copy`/`sync` as an optional extra step, very much like `--create-empty-src-dirs`.

My use case is that my Google Drive currently has all the correct modtimes of my folders, and when I use rclone to `sync` them to a new computer, I want to be able to follow that with a command to copy over all the folder modtimes from `drive` to `local`. Modtime is the main piece of dir metadata I care about (especially because of [macOS "packages"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Package_(macOS)) which are really dirs), so in my opinion, a command like this would deliver a lot of value for relatively little effort. 

Is this something you'd want?

I'm currently thinking about metadata for directories.

> I had a quick thought about this. Would it be of interest if I could write a small command that copies dir modtimes from one remote to another (for backends that support it)? It would be intended as more of a short-term stop-gap to tide us over while we wait hopefully for full dir metadata support, which would be a much more complicated project.
> 
> Many backends (including `local` and `drive`) already support listing directory modtime, like:
> 
> ```
> rclone lsf --dirs-only -R --format "pt" src_remote:path
> ```
> 
> So the command I'm imagining would do basically the equivalent of the above command, then loop through all the results and do something like `err = dir.SetModTime(ctx, t)` for each corresponding dir on the dest. (Probably with a `--modify-window` check first, and maybe also support for `--update`.)

The problem with this idea is that directories don't support `SetModTime` at the moment. This is something which will need to be added to backends to support it.

> An alternate approach might be to tack it on to the end of `copy`/`sync` as an optional extra step, very much like `--create-empty-src-dirs`.

That is my ultimate plan :-)
 
> My use case is that my Google Drive currently has all the correct modtimes of my folders, and when I use rclone to `sync` them to a new computer, I want to be able to follow that with a command to copy over all the folder modtimes from `drive` to `local`. Modtime is the main piece of dir metadata I care about (especially because of [macOS "packages"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Package_(macOS)) which are really dirs), so in my opinion, a command like this would deliver a lot of value for relatively little effort.
> 
> Is this something you'd want?

It is a very useful thing. However it is not at all a straight forward bit of work since the assumption that rclone can create and destroy directories whenever it wants is baked into every backend.

Some backends will need the modtime of directories updating if you write files in them, but I imagine some won't.

I have to remove all my data from Gdrive so now I'll have all folders without the good metadata in Dropbox.

So I backuped folders metadata in a local folder with only folders (no files), I hope if you can add this option, I will have the possibility to update my dropbox folders from "Jan  1  2000" to the good value with my local backup folder.

I'm added simple example add metadata for local backend
https://github.com/rclone/rclone/compare/master...lxShaDoWxl:rclone:master

issue.title: bisync: optimize --resync

milestone.title: Known Problem
milestone.description: This milestone contains issues which are known problems which are proving difficult to fix, or are awaiting an external fix or we haven't got round to yet.

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
## Synposis

Clearly explain in documentation whether `--resync` is asymmetrical.
(@cjnaz could you comment?)

Investigate whether `--resync` can be re-implemented by the equivalent of:

```
rclone copy --update Path1 Path2
rclone copy --update Path2 Path1
```

## Prior discussions

## optimize --resync

### https://github.com/cjnaz/rclonesync-V2/issues/66 (eric-void) -> (cjnaz)

> looking at the code there is a lot of work to copy Path2 files not in Path1, and then do an "rclone sync" from Path1 to Path2. Why don't you just do and "rclone copy" from Path1 to Path2, and then an "rclone copy" from Path2 to Path1?
> This is much simpler, there is no need to read 2 times LSL files and to loop for missing Path2 files, and the result should be the same. Am i missing something?

The first-sync optimization is deferred for now since its not broke and should be rarely run.

### https://github.com/rclone/rclone/pull/5164#discussion_r688913159 (ncw)

So `--resync` is asymetrical?

Perhaps it would be better implemented by the equivalent of

```
rclone copy --update Path1 Path2
rclone copy --update Path2 Path1
```

## How to use GitHub

* Please use the üëç [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

body:
> Would it be of interest if I could write a small command that copies dir modtimes from one remote to another (for backends that support it)? It would be intended as more of a short-term stop-gap to tide us over while we wait hopefully for full dir metadata support, which would be a much more complicated project.

For whatever it's worth -- I ended up creating this command for my personal use, and it is working beautifully for my purposes. You are right that it required adding a new optional interface, but once I did that, I was surprised at how minimal the other required changes were. About 8 lines of code each for `local`, `drive`, `sftp`, and `crypt`. A tiny change, but it packs a lot of punch üôÇ 

If by chance you are interested in taking a look, here are the backend fixes: https://github.com/nielash/rclone/commit/c734b0cbece78a04b92fdf3a9e4e0019cf29a0c7 and then using it in commands: https://github.com/nielash/rclone/commit/3b1d55ae0b95e09a9c0aca4ff40514b05ab5453d

I'm sure your eventual fix will be better, but I think having _something_ is a lot better than nothing in the meantime for this [much](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/1669)-[requested](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/977) feature. It is so nice to see the correct years on my project folders again üôÇ 

P.S. Thank you for the `--metadata-mapper`! Very clever concept, and I've already put it to use!

> For whatever it's worth -- I ended up creating this command for my personal use, and it is working beautifully for my purposes. You are right that it required adding a new optional interface, but once I did that, I was surprised at how minimal the other required changes were. About 8 lines of code each for `local`, `drive`, `sftp`, and `crypt`. A tiny change, but it packs a lot of punch üôÇ

Wow, great work @nielash ! I've been wanting this functionality for so long and it appears that you've implemented support for it in a way that will work for me. I'm going to build your fork and give it a try but just from a cursory glance at the source, it looks like it will do exactly what I want. Thanks for sharing this!
